content.p: lessen significantly the amenity of the land or the surrounding area,
substantially prejudice the use of the whole of the land comprising the small landholding for cultivation in the future,
be substantially detrimental to the sound management of the estate of which the land consists or forms part, or
cause the landlord to suffer undue hardship,

where the notice specifies a matter mentioned in paragraph 7(3)(b)(ii) or (iii), the landlord reasonably considers that it fails to demonstrate that the proposed changes are, or, as the case may be, the business (so far as relating to the land) is, viable, or
the landholder has failed to comply with paragraph 8(3).
Where the landlord agrees to the proposal, the landlord may impose on the landholder any reasonable conditions in relation to the implementation of the proposal.

intro.p: Notification under sub-paragraph (1) must—

content.p: where the landlord objects to the proposal, set out the grounds for the objection,
where the landlord imposes conditions under sub-paragraph (4), set out the conditions and the reasons for imposing them, and
explain why the landlord considers the grounds or (as the case may be) conditions are reasonable.
The landlord is to be treated as having agreed to the proposal (without imposing any conditions on the landholder) if the landlord does not notify the landholder in accordance with sub-paragraph (1).

intro.p: Where the landlord agrees to the proposal, the proposal may be implemented, subject to any conditions imposed under sub-paragraph (4), from either—
the later of—

content.p: the date specified in the notice under paragraph 7(2)(d), and
where the landlord has made a request for information under paragraph 8(1), the date falling 70 days from the making of the request, or
such earlier date as the landlord and the landholder may agree to.

intro.p: The Scottish Ministers may by regulations—

content.p: modify sub-paragraph (3) so as to add or remove a ground for objection to a proposal,

intro.p: make provision about—

content.p: information to be included in a notice given under sub-paragraph (1)(b) in relation to each ground of objection,
the manner in which that information is to be provided.
This paragraph applies where a landlord notifies a small landholder under paragraph 9(1)(b) that the landlord objects to a diversification proposal in a notice of diversification.

The landholder may, within the period of 30 days beginning with the day on which notification of the objection is given, notify the landlord in writing that the landholder wishes to negotiate a diversification agreement with the landlord.

intro.p: Where, following notification being given under sub-paragraph (2), the landholder and the landlord enter into a diversification agreement, the notice of diversification is to be treated as if it had not been given if—

content.p: the agreement is entered into within the period of 90 days beginning with the day on which notification of the objection was given under paragraph 9(1), and
when the agreement is entered into, the landlord has not made an application to the Land Court under paragraph 13(2) in relation to the objection (but see paragraph 14).
Sub-paragraph (5) applies where the landholder notifies the landlord under sub-paragraph (2) that the landholder wishes to negotiate with the landlord.

intro.p: The period within which the landlord may—

content.p: withdraw the objection to the diversification proposal in the notice of diversification under paragraph 11(1), or
make an application to the Land Court under paragraph 13(2) in relation to the objection,

wrapUp.p: is, instead of the period mentioned in paragraph 11(1) or (as the case may be) 13(3), the period of 90 days beginning with the day on which the objection is notified under paragraph 9(1)(b).

content.p: A landlord may withdraw an objection to a diversification proposal notified to a small landholder under paragraph 9(1)(b) within the period of 60 days beginning with the day on which it is notified.

intro.p: Where the landlord withdraws the objection, the landlord—

content.p: must notify the landholder in writing of the withdrawal, and that the landlord now agrees to the proposal, and
may impose on the landholder any reasonable conditions in relation to the implementation of the proposal.

intro.p: Where the landlord imposes conditions under sub-paragraph (2)(b), the landlord must, at the same time as notifying the landholder of the withdrawal of the objection, notify the landholder in writing of—

content.p: the conditions and the reasons for imposing them, and
why the landlord considers the conditions are reasonable.

intro.p: Where the objection is withdrawn under sub-paragraph (1)—
the proposal may be implemented, subject to any conditions imposed under sub-paragraph (2)(b), from the later of—

content.p: the date specified in the notice of diversification under paragraph 7(2)(d), and
the date on which the landlord notifies the landholder of the withdrawal under sub-paragraph (2)(a), and
the landlord may not make an application to the Land Court under paragraph 13(2) in relation to the proposal.
This paragraph applies where a landlord imposes conditions on a small landholder in relation to the implementation of a diversification proposal under paragraph 9(4) or 11(2)(b).

intro.p: The landlord may, within the period of 60 days beginning with the day on which the conditions are notified to the landholder—

content.p: withdraw the conditions, or
modify the conditions.
The landlord must notify the landholder in writing that the conditions are withdrawn or (as the case may be) modified.

intro.p: Where the landlord modifies the conditions under sub-paragraph (2)(b), the landlord must notify the landholder in writing of—

content.p: the modifications to the conditions and the reasons for making them, and
why the landlord considers the conditions, as modified, are reasonable.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Determination of Land Court in relation to objection to diversification

content.p: This paragraph applies where a landlord notifies a small landholder under paragraph 9(1)(b) that the landlord objects to a diversification proposal.
The landlord may, within the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (3), apply to the Land Court for a determination that the objection is reasonable.
That period is the period of 60 days beginning with the day on which the objection is notified under paragraph 9(1)(b).

intro.p: The Land Court may determine that the objection is—

content.p: reasonable, or
unreasonable.
Where the Land Court determines that the objection is reasonable, the landholder may not implement the proposal.

intro.p: Where the Land Court determines that the objection is unreasonable, the Court—
must—

content.p: approve the proposal, and
determine the date from which the proposal may be implemented, and
may impose on the landholder such reasonable conditions in relation to the implementation of the proposal as it considers appropriate.

intro.p: In deciding whether or not it is reasonable for the landlord to object to a notice of diversification, the Land Court is to—

content.p: consider if the intended use of the land for the diverse purpose is likely to have a positive effect on the environment, and

if the Land Court considers such positive effects are likely, whether those positive effects outweigh any negative effects (including, in particular, any negative effects mentioned in paragraph 9(3)(a)(i) to (iii)).

intro.p: Where the landlord does not make an application under sub-paragraph (2) (and does not withdraw the objection under paragraph 11(1))—

content.p: the proposal is to be treated as having been agreed to by the landlord on the expiry of the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (3) (as read with paragraph 10(5)), and

intro.p: the proposal may be implemented from the later of—

content.p: the date specified in the notice of diversification under paragraph 7(2)(d), and
the date on which the proposal is treated as having been agreed to.

intro.p: Where the landlord withdraws or abandons an application under sub-paragraph (2)—

content.p: the proposal is to be treated as having been agreed to by the landlord on the day on which the application is withdrawn or treated as having been abandoned, and

intro.p: the proposal may be implemented from the later of—

content.p: the date specified in the notice of diversification under paragraph 7(2)(d), and
the date on which the proposal is treated as having been agreed to.

An application purportedly made under sub-paragraph (2) after the end of the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (3) (as read with paragraph 10(5)) is to be treated as not having been made (and the Land Court may not make a determination under this paragraph in respect of it).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Diversification agreement entered into during proceedings under paragraph 13

intro.p: This paragraph applies where the landlord and the small landholder of a small landholding enter into a diversification agreement—

content.p: after the landlord makes an application to the Land Court under paragraph 13(1), but
before the Land Court makes a determination in relation to that application under paragraph 13(4).

intro.p: The Land Court may, on the application of the landlord or the landholder, instead of determining the application under paragraph 13(4), determine that the diversification proposal to which the application relates—

content.p: is not approved by the Court, and
accordingly, is not to be implemented.
But nothing in sub-paragraph (2) prevents a landholder using land in accordance with the diversification agreement.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Application by landholder to Land Court to remove conditions

content.p: Where a landlord imposes a condition on a small landholder under paragraph 9(4) or 11(2)(b), the landholder may, before the end of the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (2), apply to the Land Court for a determination that the condition is unreasonable.
That period is 60 days beginning with the day on which notification of the conditions is given under paragraph 9(5)(b) or (as the case may be) 11(3).

Where a landlord modifies a condition under paragraph 12(2), the landholder may, before the end of the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (4), apply to the Land Court for a determination that the condition as modified is unreasonable.
That period is 60 days beginning with the day on which notification of the modification is given under paragraph 12(3).

intro.p: In deciding whether or not a condition is unreasonable, the Land Court is to—

content.p: consider if the intended use of the land for the diverse purpose is likely to have a positive effect on the environment, and

if the Land Court considers such positive effects are likely, whether those positive effects outweigh any negative effects (including, in particular, any negative effects mentioned in paragraph 9(3)(a)(i) to (iii)) to which the condition relates.

intro.p: Where, on an application under sub-paragraph (1) or (3), the Land Court determines that the condition is unreasonable, the Court may—

content.p: remove the condition, and
in its place, impose on the landholder such reasonable conditions as it considers appropriate.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Use of land other than for cultivation

content.p: A small landholding does not cease to be a small landholding by reason only that the land comprising the holding, or part of it, is used for a diverse purpose if the use of the land for that purpose is in accordance with a diversification agreement or an authorised diversification proposal.

Any term of the lease of the holding which prohibits the use of the land comprising the holding, or part of it, for a diverse purpose is of no effect in relation to the use of the land in accordance with a diversification agreement or an authorised diversification proposal.

intro.p: In this paragraph, “authorised diversification proposal” means a diversification proposal which is—

content.p: agreed to by a landlord under this Part, or
approved by the Land Court under paragraph 13(6)(a)(i).

intro.p: In this Part—

content.p: cultivation means the use of land for horticulture or husbandry,
diverse purpose has the meaning given by paragraph 6(1),
diversification agreement means an agreement under paragraph 6(2),
diversification proposal has the meaning given by paragraph 7(6),
notice of diversification has the meaning given by paragraph 7(1).

part.heading: Disposal of holding by small landholder

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Renunciation of tenancy by small landholder

content.p: A small landholder may, on giving 1 year’s written notice to the landlord, renounce the landholder’s tenancy with effect as from any term of Whitsunday or Martinmas.

But where the landholder is a new holder, unless the landlord agrees otherwise, the tenancy may be renounced only with effect as from the same term of Whitsunday or Martinmas from which it took effect.
In this paragraph, “new holder” means a new landholder, or the successor of a new landholder, for the purposes of section 2(1) of the Small Landholders (Scotland) Act 1911.

A small landholder may assign the landholder’s interest in a small landholding to any one of the persons mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) if, following notice under sub-paragraph (4), the landlord of the holding consents to the proposed assignation.

intro.p: The persons referred to in sub-paragraph (1) are—

content.p: any person who would be, or would in any circumstances have been, entitled to succeed to the landholder’s estate on intestacy by virtue of the Succession (Scotland) Act 1964,

intro.p: the spouse or civil partner of—

content.p: the landholder’s descendant,
the landholder’s sibling,

intro.p: in relation to the landholder’s spouse or civil partner—

content.p: that person’s sibling,
a spouse or civil partner of such a sibling,
a descendant of such a sibling.

intro.p: For the purpose of sub-paragraph (2)—

content.p: a reference to the spouse or civil partner of a person (“person A”) includes a reference to the person who was the spouse or civil partner of person A immediately prior to person A’s death,
two people are siblings if they have at least one parent in common,

a step-child or, as the case may be, step-sibling of a person is to be treated as being the same as a child or, as the case may be, sibling of a person (and sub-paragraph (2)(a) is to be read as if the rules of intestacy applied accordingly).

intro.p: A landholder who intends to assign the interest in a holding by virtue of this paragraph must—

content.p: give the landlord of the holding notice in writing (referred to in this schedule as a “notice of proposed assignation”) at least 70 days prior to the date on which the assignation takes effect, and

intro.p: specify in the notice—

content.p: the particulars of the proposed assignee (including the proposed assignee’s relationship to the landholder),
the terms upon which the assignation is to be granted, and
the date on which the assignation is to take effect.

intro.p: A landlord who is given a notice of proposed assignation is deemed to consent to the proposed assignation unless, within the period of 28 days beginning with the date on which the notice is given, the landlord gives the landholder a notice in writing—

content.p: indicating that consent to the proposed assignation is withheld, and
setting out the landlord’s grounds for withholding consent (see paragraph 20).

Any term of a lease or of an agreement between a landlord and a small landholder which purports to provide that the landholder’s interest in the holding may not be assigned in accordance with this paragraph, or in accordance with an order of the Land Court under paragraph 20(6), is, in so far as it so purports, null and void.

intro.p: Where an assignation is proposed in accordance with paragraph 19 and the proposed assignee is a near relative of the small landholder, the only grounds on which the landlord of the small landholding may withhold consent are that—

content.p: the person is not of good character,
the person does not have sufficient resources to be able to cultivate the holding with reasonable efficiency, or
the person has neither sufficient training nor sufficient experience to be able to cultivate the holding with reasonable efficiency.

intro.p: But the ground of objection in sub-paragraph (1)(c) does not apply where the person—

content.p: is engaged in or will begin, before the end of the period of 6 months beginning with the date on which the notice of proposed assignation is given, a course of relevant training in cultivation of land which the person is expected to complete satisfactorily within 4 years from that date, and
has made arrangements to secure that the holding is cultivated with reasonable efficiency until the person completes that course.

Where an assignation is proposed in accordance with paragraph 19(1) and the proposed assignee is not a near relative of the landholder, the landlord of the holding may withhold consent if there are reasonable grounds for doing so.

intro.p: In particular, the landlord has reasonable grounds for withholding consent where the proposed assignee—
would not have the ability to pay—

content.p: the rent due in respect of the holding, or
for adequate cultivation of the holding, or
does not have the skills or experience that would be required properly to cultivate the holding.

If a landlord gives a notice under paragraph 19(5) withholding consent to a proposed assignation, the landholder may, within the period of 28 days beginning with the date on which that notice is given, apply to the Land Court for an order authorising the proposed assignation.

If, on the hearing of such an application, the Land Court is satisfied that none of the grounds for withholding consent set out in the notice under paragraph 19(5) are reasonable, it must make an order authorising the proposed assignation.
In any other case, the Land Court must dismiss the application.
A decision of the Land Court under this paragraph is final.

intro.p: For the purposes of this paragraph, a near relative, in relation to a small landholder, means—

content.p: the landholder’s parent,

intro.p: in relation to the landholder’s child—

content.p: that child,
that child’s spouse or civil partner,
a descendant of that child,

intro.p: in relation to the landholder’s sibling—

content.p: that sibling,
that sibling’s spouse or civil partner,
a descendant of that sibling,

intro.p: in relation to the landholder’s spouse or civil partner—

content.p: that spouse or civil partner,
that spouse or civil partner’s sibling,
a spouse or civil partner of such a sibling,
a descendant of such a sibling.

intro.p: For the purpose of sub-paragraph (9)—

content.p: a reference to the spouse or civil partner of a person (“person A”) includes a reference to the person who was the spouse or civil partner of person A immediately prior to person A’s death,
a step-child of a person is to be treated as being the same as a child of a person.
A small landholder may, by will or other testamentary writing, bequeath the landholder’s interest in a small landholding to any one of the persons mentioned in sub-paragraph (2).

intro.p: The persons referred to in sub-paragraph (1) are—

content.p: any person who would be, or would in any circumstances have been, entitled to succeed to the landholder’s estate on intestacy by virtue of the Succession (Scotland) Act 1964,

intro.p: the spouse or civil partner of—

content.p: the landholder’s descendant,
the landholder’s sibling,

intro.p: in relation to the landholder’s spouse or civil partner—

content.p: that person’s sibling,
a spouse or civil partner of such a sibling,
a descendant of such a sibling.

intro.p: For the purpose of sub-paragraph (2)—

content.p: a reference to the spouse or civil partner of a person (“person A”) includes a reference to the person who was the spouse or civil partner of person A immediately prior to person A’s death,
two people are siblings if they have at least one parent in common,

a step-child or, as the case may be, step-sibling is to be treated as being the same as a child or, as the case may be, sibling (and sub-paragraph (2)(a) is to be read as if the rules of intestacy applied accordingly).
Sub-paragraph (5) applies where a person to whom a small landholder’s interest in a holding is bequeathed (referred to in this schedule as the “legatee”) accepts the bequest.

intro.p: The legatee must give the landlord of the holding written notice of the bequest and the legatee’s acceptance of it—

content.p: before the end of the period of 21 days beginning with the date of death of the landholder, or
where the legatee is unavoidably unable to give notice within the period specified in paragraph (a), as soon as practicable thereafter.
A notice under sub-paragraph (5) must specify the legatee’s relationship to the deceased landholder.

Unless a counter-notice is given by the landlord in accordance with paragraph 23(2) or 24(2), the giving of a notice under sub-paragraph (5) has the effect of making the deceased landholder’s lease of the holding binding on the landlord and the legatee, as landlord and tenant respectively, from the date of the deceased’s death.

intro.p: A small landholder’s interest in a small landholding is, on the landholder’s death, to be treated as intestate estate of the deceased in accordance with Part 1 of the Succession (Scotland) Act 1964 where—

content.p: it is not the subject of a valid bequest by the deceased, or

intro.p: it is the subject of such a bequest, but the bequest—

content.p: is not accepted by the legatee,

is the subject of a counter-notice under paragraph 24(2) declaring it to be null and void, and either no appeal is made to the Land Court within the period permitted for doing so or any such appeal is withdrawn, or
is declared, or confirmed, to be null and void by the Land Court under paragraph 23(6)(a) or 24(5).

intro.p: A person to whom a landholder’s interest in a small landholding is transferred under section 16 of the Succession (Scotland) Act 1964 (referred to in this schedule as “the acquirer”) must give written notice of the acquisition to the landlord of the holding—

content.p: before the end of the period of 21 days beginning with the date of acquisition of the interest in the holding, or
where the acquirer is unavoidably unable to give notice within the period specified in paragraph (a), as soon as practicable thereafter.
A notice under sub-paragraph (2) must specify the acquirer’s relationship to the deceased landholder.

Unless a counter-notice is given by the landlord in accordance with paragraph 23(2) or 24(2), the giving of a notice under sub-paragraph (2) has the effect of making the deceased landholder’s lease of the holding binding on the landlord and the acquirer, as landlord and tenant respectively, from the date of the deceased’s death.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Landlord’s objection to successor: near relatives

content.p: This paragraph applies where a landlord is given a notice under paragraph 21(5) or 22(2) by a legatee or (as the case may be) acquirer who is a near relative of the deceased.

intro.p: The landlord may, within the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the notice is given, give the person a counter-notice—

content.p: indicating that the landlord objects to the person’s succession to the small landholding, and
setting out the landlord’s grounds for objecting.

intro.p: The only grounds on which the landlord may object to the person’s succession to the holding are that—

content.p: the person is not of good character,
the person does not have sufficient resources to be able to cultivate the holding with reasonable efficiency,
the person has neither sufficient training nor sufficient experience to be able to cultivate the holding with reasonable efficiency.

intro.p: But the ground of objection in sub-paragraph (3)(c) does not apply where the person—

content.p: is engaged in or will begin, before the end of the period of 6 months beginning with the date on which the notice under paragraph 21(5) or 22(2) is given, a course of relevant training in cultivation of land which the person is expected to complete satisfactorily within 4 years from that date, and
has made arrangements to secure that the holding is cultivated with reasonable efficiency until the person completes that course.

intro.p: If the landlord gives a counter-notice under sub-paragraph (2), the landlord may, within the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the counter-notice is given, apply to the Land Court for an order—

content.p: in the case of a legatee, declaring the bequest to be null and void,
in the case of an acquirer, terminating the lease.

intro.p: If, on the hearing of such an application, a ground of objection set out in the counter-notice is established to the satisfaction of the Land Court, it must make an order—

content.p: in the case of a legatee, declaring the bequest to be null and void,
in the case of an acquirer, terminating the lease with effect as from such term of Whitsunday or Martinmas as the court specifies.

In any other case, the Land Court must make an order declaring the deceased small landholder’s lease of the holding to be binding on the landlord and the legatee or (as the case may be) acquirer, as landlord and tenant respectively, from the date of the deceased’s death.
A decision of the Land Court under this paragraph is final.

Where the landlord does not apply to the Land Court under sub-paragraph (5), the deceased landholder’s lease of the holding is to be binding on the landlord and the legatee or (as the case may be) acquirer, as landlord and tenant respectively, from the date of the deceased’s death.

intro.p: For the purposes of this Chapter, a near relative, in relation to a small landholder, means—

content.p: the landholder’s parent,

intro.p: in relation to the landholder’s child—

content.p: that child,
that child’s spouse or civil partner,
a descendant of that child,

intro.p: in relation to the landholder’s sibling—

content.p: that sibling,
that sibling’s spouse or civil partner,
a descendant of that sibling,

intro.p: in relation to the landholder’s spouse or civil partner—

content.p: that spouse or civil partner,
that spouse or civil partner’s sibling,
a spouse or civil partner of such a sibling,
a descendant of such a sibling.

intro.p: For the purpose of sub-paragraph (10)—

content.p: a reference to the spouse or civil partner of a person (“person A”) includes a reference to the person who was the spouse or civil partner of person A immediately prior to person A’s death,
a step-child of a person is to be treated as being the same as a child of a person.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Landlord’s objection to successor: other persons

content.p: This paragraph applies where a landlord is given a notice under paragraph 21(5) or 22(2) by a legatee or (as the case may be) acquirer who is not a near relative of the deceased.

intro.p: The landlord may, within the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the notice is given, give the person a counter-notice—

content.p: indicating that the landlord objects to the person’s succession to the small landholding,
setting out the landlord’s grounds for objecting, and

intro.p: either—

content.p: in the case of a legatee, declaring the bequest to be null and void, or

in the case of an acquirer, terminating the lease with effect as from such term of Whitsunday or Martinmas as the landlord specifies, being a term at least 1 year but no more than 2 years from the date of the counter-notice.

If the landlord gives a counter-notice under sub-paragraph (2), the person to whom it is given may, within the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the counter-notice is given, appeal to the Land Court.

intro.p: If, on the hearing of such an appeal, any reasonable ground stated by the person—

content.p: in the case of a legatee, for not declaring the bequest to be null and void, or
in the case of an acquirer, for not terminating the lease,

wrapUp.p: is established to the satisfaction of the Land Court, it must make an order quashing the counter-notice.

content.p: In any other case, the Land Court must make an order confirming the counter-notice.

Where the Land Court quashes a counter-notice under sub-paragraph (4), the deceased small landholder’s lease of the holding is, accordingly, to be binding on the landlord and the legatee or (as the case may be) acquirer, as landlord and tenant respectively, from the date of the deceased’s death.
A decision of the Land Court under this paragraph is final.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Landlord’s objection to successor: right to temporary occupation

content.p: From the date of the deceased small landholder’s death until the conclusion of any proceedings under paragraph 23 or 24, the legatee or (as the case may be) acquirer is entitled to possession of the small landholding in question.

intro.p: But sub-paragraph (1) does not apply—

content.p: where the executor in whom the landholder’s interest in the lease is vested under section 14 of the Succession (Scotland) Act 1964 objects, or
where, on the application of the landlord, the Land Court directs otherwise on cause shown.
A decision of the Land Court under this paragraph is final.

intro.p: Paragraphs 27 and 28 apply where—

content.p: a small landholder is removed from a small landholding,
a small landholder renounces the tenancy of a small landholding (see paragraph 18),
a small landholder enters into a new tenancy, to which the Landholders Acts do not apply, of the land comprising the landholder’s small landholding, or
in the case of a tenancy of a small landholding which forms part of the estate of a deceased small landholder, one of the conditions mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) is met.

intro.p: The conditions referred to in sub-paragraph (1)(d) are that—

content.p: the tenancy is terminated by virtue of subsection (3) of section 16 of the Succession (Scotland) Act 1964,
following transfer to an acquirer under that section, the tenancy is terminated by the Land Court under paragraph 23(5), or

intro.p: following such transfer, the tenancy is the subject of a counter-notice under paragraph 24(2) declaring it to be terminated and either—

content.p: no appeal is made to the Land Court within the period permitted for doing so, or any appeal made is withdrawn, or
the Land Court confirms the counter notice under paragraph 24(5).

intro.p: Where paragraphs 27 and 28 apply by reason of sub-paragraph (1)(d)—
any compensation that arises under those paragraphs is due to—

content.p: where the condition in sub-paragraph (2)(a) is met, the estate of the deceased landholder,
where the condition in sub-paragraph (2)(b) or (c) is met, the acquirer to whom the tenancy was transferred, and
Chapter 3 applies to the executor or (as the case may be) the acquirer in respect of that compensation as if the person were a small landholder.

For the purposes of sub-paragraph (1)(a) and (b), a landholder is not to be treated as having been removed from a small landholding or as having renounced a tenancy of it if the landholder continues in occupation of it under a new tenancy to which the Landholders Acts apply.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Small landholder’s right to compensation: improvements

intro.p: The small landholder is entitled to compensation from the landlord of the small landholding where—

content.p: a permanent improvement has been made to the holding,
the improvement is suitable to the holding,
the improvement was made or paid for by the landholder or the landholder’s predecessors under the same tenancy, and

intro.p: either—

content.p: the improvement was not made in order to comply with a specific written agreement, or
it was made for such a reason but fair consideration (by way of reduction of rent or otherwise) was not received for the improvement.

The amount of compensation payable under sub-paragraph (1) is an amount equal to the value of the permanent improvement to an incoming tenant of the holding after deduction of the value of any consideration or assistance (financial or otherwise) given in respect of the improvement by the landlord, or the landlord’s predecessors in title, to the landholder or the landholder’s predecessors under the same tenancy.

intro.p: In this Part—
permanent improvement means—
an improvement relating to—

content.p: a dwelling-house,
work carried out in implementation of an HRA action plan included in an HRA designation order made under section 1 of the Housing (Scotland) Act 2006 (Housing renewal areas: criteria),
farm offices,
subsoil or other drains,
walls or fences,
deep trenching,
clearing the ground,
planting trees,
making piers or landing stages,
roads suitable for pedestrian and vehicular traffic from the holding to a public road (as defined in section 151 of the Roads (Scotland) Act 1984) or the sea shore,
any other improvement which the Land Court considers adds to the value of a holding to an incoming tenant,
predecessor under the same tenancy does not include a sub-tenant.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Small landholder’s right to compensation: increase in value due to diversification

intro.p: The small landholder is entitled to compensation from the landlord of the small landholding where—

content.p: during the tenancy, the use of any part of the holding, or a change to any part of it, for a purpose other than cultivation has increased the value of the holding from what it would otherwise have been,
the use or change occurred wholly on or after the coming into force of this paragraph, and
the use or change was authorised in accordance with Part 2.

intro.p: The amount of compensation payable under sub-paragraph (1) is an amount equal to the value of the use or change in question to an incoming tenant of the holding after deduction of—

content.p: any benefit which the landlord or the landlord’s predecessor in title has given, or has agreed in writing to give, the landholder or the landholder’s predecessors under the same tenancy in consideration of the use or change in question, and
any grant which has been or will be made to the landholder, or the landholder’s predecessors under the same tenancy, in respect of the use or change in question.

But where an incoming tenant’s ability to use the whole of the land comprised in the holding for the purposes of cultivation is substantially prejudiced as a result of the use or change in question, no compensation is payable under sub-paragraph (1) unless the use or change has an environmental benefit.

intro.p: Paragraphs 30 and 31 apply where—

content.p: a small landholder is removed from a small landholding,
a small landholder renounces the tenancy of a small landholding (see paragraph 18),
a small landholder enters into a new tenancy, to which the Landholders Acts do not apply, of the land comprising the landholder’s small landholding,
a small landholder abandons the tenancy of a small landholding, or
in the case of a tenancy of a small landholding which forms part of the estate of a deceased small landholder, one of the conditions mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) is met.

intro.p: The conditions referred to in sub-paragraph (1)(e) are that—

content.p: the tenancy is terminated by virtue of subsection (3) of section 16 of the Succession (Scotland) Act 1964,
following transfer to an acquirer under that section, the tenancy is terminated by the Land Court under paragraph 23(5), or

intro.p: following such transfer, the tenancy is the subject of a counter-notice under paragraph 24(2) declaring it to be terminated, and either—

content.p: no appeal is made to the Land Court within the period permitted for doing so, or any appeal made is withdrawn, or
the Land Court confirms the counter notice under paragraph 24(5).

intro.p: Where paragraphs 30 and 31 apply by reason of sub-paragraph (1)(e)—
any compensation that arises under those paragraphs is due by—

content.p: where the condition in sub-paragraph (2)(a) is met, the estate of the deceased landholder,
where the condition in sub-paragraph (2)(b) or (c) is met, the acquirer to whom the tenancy was transferred, and
Chapter 3 applies to the executor or (as the case may be) the acquirer in respect of that compensation as if the person were a small landholder.

For the purposes of sub-paragraph (1)(a) and (b), a landholder is not to be treated as having been removed from a small landholding or as having renounced a tenancy of it if the landholder continues in occupation of it under a new tenancy to which the Landholders Acts apply.
Where a landholder abandons a tenancy of a small landholding, the tenancy is to be treated for the purposes of this Part as having been terminated.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Landlord’s right to compensation: deterioration etc. of holding.

intro.p: The landlord of the small landholding is entitled to compensation from the small landholder where—

content.p: there is dilapidation, deterioration or damage to any part of the holding, or to anything in or on the holding, and

the dilapidation, deterioration or damage is the result of the landholder, or the landholder’s predecessor under the same tenancy, failing to fulfil that person’s responsibility to cultivate the holding or to use it in accordance with a use or change authorised in accordance with Part 2.

intro.p: The amount of compensation payable under sub-paragraph (1) is whichever is the greater of—

content.p: an amount equal to the amount (if any) by which the value of the holding is reduced from what it would have been without the dilapidation, deterioration or damage in question,
the cost, as at the relevant date, of making good the dilapidation, deterioration or damage in question.

intro.p: For the purpose of sub-paragraph (2), the relevant date is—
where the right to compensation arises due to renunciation or removal, whichever is the later of—

content.p: the date of the landholder’s quitting the holding,
the date of termination of the tenancy,
in any other case, the date of termination of the tenancy.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Landlord’s right to compensation: decrease in value due to diversification

intro.p: The landlord of the small landholding is entitled to compensation from the small landholder where—

content.p: during the tenancy, the use of any part of the holding, or a change to any part of it, for a purpose other than cultivation has reduced the value of the holding from what it would otherwise have been, and
that use or change occurred wholly on or after the coming into force of this paragraph.
Sub-paragraph (1) applies regardless of whether or not the use or change in question was authorised in accordance with Part 2.

The amount of compensation payable under sub-paragraph (1) is an amount equal to the amount by which the value of the holding is reduced from what it would have been without the use or change in question.

intro.p: Compensation is recoverable by a landlord under paragraph 30 or 31 only where—

content.p: at least 3 months prior to the termination of the tenancy, the landlord gives notice in writing to the small landholder of the landlord’s intention to claim compensation,
the landholder abandons the small landholding, or
the Land Court agrees that the requirement for notice should be dispensed with in all the circumstances of the case.

Where a small landholder has remained in occupation of a small landholding during more than one tenancy, neither the landholder nor the landlord is deprived of a right to compensation under this Chapter by reason only that the thing which would give rise to the right to compensation occurred during a previous tenancy of the landholder’s.

Where compensation is due to a small landholder by a landlord under Chapter 1, any sum of rent due or to become due by the landholder in respect of the small landholding may be offset against that compensation.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Compensation to outgoing landholder by incoming landholder

content.p: This paragraph applies where an incoming tenant of a small landholding (the “incoming landholder”) agrees with the outgoing small landholder of the holding (the “outgoing landholder”) and the landlord of the holding to take on the outgoing landholder’s rights and liabilities in respect of any rights to compensation which would otherwise arise under this Part.

intro.p: The incoming landholder is to be treated for the purposes of calculation of compensation under this Part as—

content.p: having been in occupation of the holding as the landholder during the outgoing landholder’s tenancy, and
having made or paid for any permanent improvements which were made or paid for by the outgoing landholder or the outgoing landholder’s predecessors under the same tenancy,

wrapUp.p: and, accordingly, the outgoing landholder has no right to, nor liability for, compensation under this Part.

content.p: A landlord or a small landholder of a small landholding may, at any time during the tenancy of the holding, require a record of condition of the holding, or part of the holding, to be made.

intro.p: A record of condition is a record specifying some or all of the following—
the condition of—

content.p: the cultivation of the holding or (as the case may be) part of the holding,
anything in or on the holding,
who has made or paid for any permanent improvements.

intro.p: A record of condition is to be made by a person appointed—

content.p: by agreement by the landlord and the landholder, or
by the Scottish Ministers on the application of either the landlord or the landholder.
The cost of making a record of condition is payable jointly by the landlord and the landholder.

intro.p: Where a person is appointed by the Scottish Ministers to make a record of condition—

content.p: the Scottish Ministers may charge such reasonable fee as they determine for making the appointment,
the remuneration payable to the person making the record is such amount as the Scottish Ministers determine,
any other expenses of, or incidental to, the making of the record are subject to taxation by the auditor of the sheriff court or, on review, by the sheriff,
the landlord and the landholder are jointly and severally liable for the cost of making the record.
The Land Court is, on an application being made to it by either party, to determine any dispute between the landlord and the landholder relating to the making of a record of condition.

chapter.heading: Process for determination of compensation amount

content.p: A landlord or small landholder may apply to the Tenant Farming Commissioner for an assessment of the amount of compensation due to or by a person under this Part in respect of a small landholding.
Any application under sub-paragraph (1) must be made no later than the end of the period of 3 months beginning with the date of termination of the tenancy of the holding.
The Scottish Ministers may by regulations prescribe the form and content of an application under sub-paragraph (1).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Appointment of valuer by Tenant Farming Commissioner

content.p: This paragraph applies where the Tenant Farming Commissioner is given an application under paragraph 36.
The Commissioner must appoint a person (referred to in this Part as the “valuer”) to carry out the assessment mentioned in paragraph 40(1).

intro.p: A person may be appointed as the valuer only where the person appears to the Commissioner—

content.p: to be independent of the landlord and the small landholder, and
to possess qualifications, knowledge and experience suitable for assessing the compensation that may be payable to landlords and landholders of small landholdings.
The valuer must be appointed before the end of the period of 28 days beginning with the date on which the application is given.
The Commissioner must give notice in writing to the landlord and the landholder of the name and address of the valuer appointed under sub-paragraph (2).
The Scottish Ministers may by regulations modify the period specified in sub-paragraph (4).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Objection to valuer appointed by Tenant Farming Commissioner

intro.p: The small landholder or, as the case may be, the landlord may apply to the Land Court to appoint a person as the valuer in place of the valuer appointed under paragraph 37(2) on the grounds that the valuer so appointed (either or both)—

content.p: is not independent of the landlord or (as the case may be) the landholder,
does not possess the qualifications, knowledge and experience mentioned in paragraph 37(3)(b).

intro.p: An application under sub-paragraph (1)—
must—

content.p: be made before the end of the period of 14 days beginning with the date on which notice of the appointment was given to the landlord or, as the case may be, landholder under paragraph 37(5), and
state the ground of objection to the valuer appointed by the Commissioner, and
may propose a person to be appointed as the valuer in place of the valuer appointed by the Commissioner.

intro.p: The Land Court may, on an application under sub-paragraph (1)—

content.p: refuse the application, or
allow the application and appoint another person as the valuer (whether a person proposed in the application or not).
The decision of the Land Court on an application under sub-paragraph (1) is final.

intro.p: Where a valuer is appointed under paragraph 37(2) or 38(3)(b), the person responsible for meeting the expenses incurred in carrying out the valuer’s functions under this Part is—

content.p: where the compensation award is in a person’s favour, the person by whom the compensation is payable,
where there is no compensation award, the person who made the application under paragraph 36(1).

Where, in the case of a valuer appointed under paragraph 37(2), those expenses have been met by the Commissioner, the Commissioner is entitled to recover them from the person by whom they are payable under sub-paragraph (1).

For the purpose of sub-paragraph (1), a compensation award is in a person’s favour where, ignoring the effect of paragraph 33, the compensation payable to the person under this Part exceeds the compensation payable by the person under it.
The valuer is to assess the amount of compensation to which the landlord or (as the case may be) small landholder is entitled under Chapter 1.

intro.p: The valuer is, prior to carrying out the assessment under sub-paragraph (1), to—

content.p: invite the landlord and the landholder to make written representations about the assessment, and
have regard to any such representations.

intro.p: For the purposes of any assessment under sub-paragraph (1), the valuer may—

content.p: enter onto land, and
require the landlord and landholder to comply with any reasonable request made by the valuer.

The Scottish Ministers may by regulations modify this paragraph so as to specify the basis on which the valuer is to assess the compensation payable and the consideration to be given to certain matters by the valuer in doing so.

intro.p: The valuer must—
give a notice in writing (referred to in this Part as a “notice of assessment”) to—

content.p: the small landholder, and
the landlord, and
at the same time, give a copy of the notice to the Tenant Farming Commissioner.

intro.p: The notice of assessment must be given before the end of the period of 8 weeks beginning with—

content.p: the day after the day on which the period for applying under paragraph 38(1) to appoint a different person as the valuer ends without such an application being made, or

intro.p: where such an application is made—

content.p: the date of the Land Court’s decision on it, or
the date on which the application is withdrawn.

intro.p: A notice of assessment must—
specify the amount, assessed under paragraph 40, of compensation—

content.p: to which the landholder is entitled under paragraphs 27 and 28,
to which the landlord is entitled under paragraphs 30 and 31,
specify the date of valuation of each of the amounts mentioned in paragraph (a),
set out how the valuer arrived at each of those amounts,
be dated.
The notice may also contain or be accompanied by any other information that the valuer considers appropriate.
The small landholder or the landlord may appeal to the Lands Tribunal against a notice of assessment.

intro.p: An appeal under this paragraph must—

content.p: state the grounds on which it is being made, and
be lodged before the end of the period of 21 days beginning with the date on which the notice of assessment is given.
The Lands Tribunal may reassess the amount of compensation assessed under paragraph 40 (and any factor affecting the amount).
The valuer whose assessment is appealed against may be a witness in the appeal proceedings.

intro.p: In the appeal proceedings, in addition to the landlord and the landholder, the following persons are entitled to be heard—

content.p: where the landlord is a creditor in a standard security, the owner of the small landholding,
where the landlord is the owner of the small landholding, any creditor in a standard security over the holding or any part of it.
The Lands Tribunal is to give written reasons for its decision on an appeal under this paragraph.
The decision of the Lands Tribunal in an appeal under this paragraph is final.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Referral of certain matters by Lands Tribunal to Land Court

content.p: This paragraph applies where, in an appeal before the Lands Tribunal under paragraph 42, an issue of law arises which may competently be determined by the Land Court by virtue of section 1(6) of the Scottish Land Court Act 1993 or this Act.
The Tribunal is to refer the issue to the Land Court for determination unless the Tribunal considers that it is not appropriate to do so.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Register of Community Interests in Land: small landholders’ interests in buying land

intro.p: In this Part—

content.p: Keeper means the person who keeps the Register of Community Interests in Land under section 36 of the Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2003,
Register means that Register.
The Keeper is to keep the Register so that there is contained in it a part for registering small landholders’ interests in buying land in accordance with paragraph 45.

intro.p: There is to be included in that part of the Register—

content.p: a record of any notice or notification given to the Keeper under this Part, and
where the registration of a landholder’s interest in buying land is removed under paragraph 47(4), an entry specifying the date on which that is effected.
A reference in this Part to a small landholder does not include a reference to a person who is a sub-tenant of a small landholding.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Registration of small landholder’s interest in buying land

content.p: A small landholder may apply to have registered an interest in buying the land comprising the landholder’s small landholding by giving a notice (a “notice of interest”) to the Keeper.

intro.p: The notice of interest must—

content.p: be in such form as the Scottish Ministers may prescribe by regulations, and

intro.p: specify—

content.p: the particulars of the landholder and the owner of the land,
the location and boundaries of the land (by reference, where appropriate, to the lease of the holding or any map or drawing),
any interest or rights comprised in the land (including any sporting or mineral rights), and
such other information as the Scottish Ministers may so prescribe.

intro.p: The landholder must—

content.p: give a copy of the notice of interest to the owner of the land, and
notify the Keeper that the copy has been so given.

intro.p: On receipt of the notice of interest, the Keeper must—
register—

content.p: the landholder’s interest in buying the land,
the details specified in the notice of interest, and
the date of registration, and
give an extract of the registration to the landholder and the owner of the land.

intro.p: Where the registration relates to land over which there is a standard security, the owner of the land must—

content.p: intimate that fact to the landholder, and
give a copy of the extract to the creditor in the standard security within the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the owner is given the extract.

intro.p: The Keeper may charge such reasonable fee as the Scottish Ministers may by regulations specify for—

content.p: registering landholders’ interests in buying land, and
providing extracts, and copy extracts, of registration.

This paragraph applies where the Keeper gives the owner of land comprising a small landholding, under paragraph 45(4)(b), an extract of the registration of the small landholder’s interest in buying the land comprising the holding.
The owner may, by notice in writing to the Keeper, challenge the registration on the grounds that any matter contained in the extract is inaccurate.
On receipt of notice under sub-paragraph (2), the Keeper is to make such enquiry in connection with the landholder’s interest as the Keeper considers appropriate.

intro.p: If, following such an enquiry, the Keeper considers that the notice of interest is inaccurate, the Keeper—

content.p: must, if the inaccuracy is material, rescind the registration of the landholder’s interest,
may, if the inaccuracy is not material, amend the registration.

intro.p: Where, under sub-paragraph (4)—

content.p: the registration is rescinded, the Keeper must intimate that fact to the landholder and the owner,
the registration is amended, the Keeper must give an extract of the registration to the landholder and the owner.
The landholder or the owner may appeal to the Land Court against any decision made, following notice under sub-paragraph (2), by the Keeper in respect of the registration.
The Court may make such order as it considers appropriate in an appeal under sub-paragraph (6).

intro.p: The registration under paragraph 45(4)(a) of a small landholder’s interest in buying land—

content.p: continues to have effect only in relation to such land as remains comprised in the landholder’s small landholding, and

intro.p: ceases to have effect—

content.p: if the registration is rescinded under paragraph 46(4)(a),
if the landholder’s tenancy of the land is terminated, or
where neither of those things has occurred, at the end of the period of 5 years beginning with the date of registration.

intro.p: The owner of the land must give notice in writing to the Keeper where—

content.p: the landholder’s tenancy of the land is terminated during the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)(b)(iii), or
there is a reduction in the land comprising the holding during that period.

Where a landholder’s interest in buying land is, or has been, registered, the landholder may at any time apply under paragraph 45(1) to have the interest registered again (with or without modification of the matters specified in the notice of interest).
The Keeper must remove from the Register any registration of a landholder’s interest in buying land which no longer has effect.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Notice of proposal to transfer land

intro.p: This paragraph applies where—

content.p: a small landholder’s interest in buying the land comprising the landholder’s small landholding has been registered under paragraph 45(4)(a), and
the registration has not ceased to have effect.

The owner of the land, and any eligible creditor in relation to the land, must, before transferring the land or any part of it to another person, give the landholder notice of any proposal by the owner or (as the case may be) the creditor to make such a transfer.
But sub-paragraph (2) does not apply if the transfer is an exempt transfer for the purposes of this paragraph (see paragraph 49).

intro.p: Notice under sub-paragraph (2) must be given—

content.p: in writing, and
in accordance with such provision (including provision as to the form of the notice) as the Scottish Ministers may prescribe by regulations.
An owner or creditor who gives a landholder notice under sub-paragraph (2) must give a copy of the notice to the Keeper.

intro.p: In this Part, “eligible creditor”, in relation to land, means a creditor in a standard security with a right to sell the land under—

content.p: section 20(2) or 23(2) of the Conveyancing and Feudal Reform (Scotland) Act 1970, or
a warrant granted under section 24(1) of that Act.

intro.p: A transfer of land is an exempt transfer for the purposes of paragraph 48 if the transfer is or (as the case may be) would be—

content.p: otherwise than for value,

in implement or pursuance of an order of a court, other than an order under section 24 of the Conveyancing and Feudal Reform (Scotland) Act 1970 or a decree in an action for the division and sale of land,
between spouses or civil partners in pursuance of an arrangement between them entered into at any time after they have ceased living together,
between companies in the same group,
to a statutory undertaker for the purpose of carrying on the undertaking,

intro.p: a transfer—

content.p: implementing the compulsory acquisition of land under any enactment,
by agreement, of land which could have been acquired compulsorily under any enactment,
implementing any right conferred by Part 2 (which provides for the community right to buy) of the Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2003 to buy land,
implementing missives for the sale and purchase of land concluded, or an option to acquire land which existed on a date on which no interest in buying the land was registered under paragraph 45,

which requires, or which but for the provisions of section 14 of the Housing (Scotland) Act 1987 would require, the consent of the Scottish Ministers under subsection (5) or (7) of section 12 of that Act,
by a registered social landlord (within the meaning of the Housing (Scotland) Act 2010) in pursuance of the power conferred by section 107 of that Act,
vesting the land in a person for the purposes of any enactment relating to sequestration, bankruptcy, winding up or incapacity or to the purposes for which judicial factors may be appointed, or

intro.p: a transfer of land in consequence of—

content.p: the assumption or resignation or death of one or more of the partners in a partnership, or
the assumption or resignation or death of one or more of the trustees of a trust.

intro.p: But, in the case of a transfer mentioned in any of paragraphs (a), (d) and (g) of sub-paragraph (1), the transfer is not an exempt transfer for the purposes of paragraph 48 if the transfer—

content.p: is or forms part of a scheme or arrangement or is one of a series of transfers, and
the main purpose or effect, or one of the main purposes or effects, of the scheme, arrangement or (as the case may be) series is the avoidance of the requirements or consequences of this Part.

For the purposes of sub-paragraph (1)(d), companies are in the same group if they are, or are included in a number of, companies which, by virtue of section 170 of the Taxation of Chargeable Gains Act 1992, together form a group for the purposes of sections 171 to 181 of that Act.
In sub-paragraph (1)(e), “statutory undertaker” is to be construed in accordance with section 214 of the Town and Country Planning (Scotland) Act 1997.
The Scottish Ministers may by regulations modify (any or all of) sub-paragraphs (1) to (4).

intro.p: Sub-paragraph (2) applies where—

content.p: the owner of land comprising a small landholding, or an eligible creditor in relation to the land comprising the holding, gives notice to the small landholder of the holding of a proposal to transfer land, or

intro.p: the owner or such a creditor takes steps with a view to the transfer of the land or any part of it and—

content.p: the transfer is a transfer in respect of which notice of a proposal to transfer land is required to be given to the landholder, and
such notice has not been given.

The landholder has the right to buy the land to which the proposed transfer relates (including any interest or rights comprised in the land) from the owner of the land or (as the case may be) the creditor.

intro.p: For the purposes of sub-paragraph (1)(b), an owner or eligible creditor takes steps with a view to a transfer of land when—

content.p: the land is, by or with the authority of the owner or creditor, advertised or otherwise exposed for sale,
the owner or the creditor, or a person acting on behalf of the owner or the creditor, enters into negotiations with another person with a view to the transfer of the land, or

the owner or the creditor, or a person acting on behalf of the owner or the creditor, proceeds further with any proposed transfer of the land which was initiated prior to the date on which the landholder’s interest in buying the land was registered.
References in sub-paragraph (3) to the owner of land include references to a person in whom the land has vested for the purposes of any such enactment as is mentioned in paragraph 49(1)(f)(vii).

intro.p: Sub-paragraph (6) applies where—

content.p: a landholder has a right to buy land under sub-paragraph (2), and
despite the existence of that right, the owner or (as the case may be) the creditor transfers the land to a person other than the landholder.
The landholder has the right to buy the land (including any interests or rights comprised in the land) from the person to whom the land is transferred or is subsequently transferred.
The Scottish Ministers may by regulations modify sub-paragraphs (3) and (4).

Where a small landholder has a right to buy land under paragraph 50(2) by virtue of paragraph 50(1)(a), the landholder may proceed in accordance with paragraph 53 to buy the land from the owner of the land or (as the case may be) the eligible creditor provided that notice is given under sub-paragraph (2).

intro.p: Notice is given under this sub-paragraph if—

content.p: the landholder gives notice to the owner or (as the case may be) the creditor that the landholder intends to buy the land, and
the notice is given within the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the landholder is given a notice of a proposal to transfer land.

Where a landholder has a right to buy under paragraph 50(2) by virtue of paragraph 50(1)(b), the landholder may proceed in accordance with paragraph 53 to buy the land from the owner or (as the case may be) the creditor provided that the landholder gives notice to the owner or, as the case may be, the creditor that the landholder intends to buy the land.

Where a landholder has a right to buy land under paragraph 50(6), the landholder may proceed in accordance with paragraph 53 to buy the land from the person to whom the land has been transferred or subsequently transferred provided that notice is given under sub-paragraph (5).

intro.p: Notice is given under this sub-paragraph if—

content.p: the landholder gives notice to that person that the landholder intends to buy the land,
the notice is given within the period of 3 years beginning with the day on which the land is transferred to that person, and
the landholder’s tenancy is in force on the date on which the notice is given.

If, at any time, the landholder does not intend to proceed, in accordance with paragraph 53, to buy the land, the landholder is to give notice of that fact to the person from whom the land would otherwise have been bought.

intro.p: The right to buy mentioned in—

content.p: sub-paragraph (1) is extinguished if the landholder does not give notice in accordance with sub-paragraph (2),
sub-paragraph (4) is extinguished if the landholder does not give notice in accordance with sub-paragraph (5),
sub-paragraph (1), (3) or (4) is extinguished if the landholder gives notice under sub-paragraph (6).
A landholder giving any notice under this paragraph must give a copy of the notice to the Keeper.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Effect of extinguishing right to buy

intro.p: Where a small landholder’s right to buy land is extinguished under paragraph 51(7) or 53(9), the landholder may acquire a subsequent right to buy the same land or any part of it under paragraph 50(2), but only if—

content.p: the period of 12 months beginning with the day on which the right to buy is extinguished has expired, or

intro.p: before that period has expired—

content.p: the land is transferred to another person, and
that person requires to give notice of a proposal to transfer land in relation to a subsequent transfer.
It is for the small landholder to make the offer to buy in exercise of the landholder’s right to buy under paragraph 50.

intro.p: The offer is to be at a price—

content.p: agreed between the landholder and the person from whom the land is to be bought (in this Part, “the seller”), or

intro.p: where there is no such agreement—

content.p: payable by the landholder in accordance with paragraph 55(9), or
if the price is determined in an appeal under paragraph 57, as is so determined.
The offer must specify the date of entry and of payment of the price in accordance with sub-paragraph (4).

intro.p: The date of entry and of payment of the price is to be—

content.p: a date not later than 6 months after the date on which the landholder gave notice under paragraph 51 of the landholder’s intention to buy,

intro.p: where the price payable by the landholder is the subject of an appeal under paragraph 57 which has not, within the period of 4 months beginning with the day on which the landholder gave such notice, been—

content.p: determined, or
abandoned following agreement between the landholder and the seller,

wrapUp.p: a date not later than 2 months after the appeal is so determined or (as the case may be) abandoned, or

content.p: such later date as may be agreed between the landholder and the seller.
The offer may include such other reasonable conditions as are necessary or expedient to secure the efficient progress and completion of the transfer.

If the landholder has not, within the period fixed by or agreed under sub-paragraph (4), done any of the things mentioned in sub-paragraph (7), the seller may apply to the Land Court for an order under sub-paragraph (8).

intro.p: The things are—

content.p: concluding missives with the seller for the sale of the land to the landholder, or
if the landholder has not so concluded missives, taking all steps which the landholder could reasonably have taken in the time available towards so concluding missives.

intro.p: An order under this sub-paragraph may—
direct the landholder—

content.p: to conclude missives with the seller within such period as may be specified in the order, and
to take such remedial action for the purpose of so concluding missives as may be so specified, and
direct the landholder and seller to incorporate into the missives any term or condition in respect of the sale of the land as may be so specified.

intro.p: The right to buy mentioned in sub-paragraph (1) is extinguished if—

content.p: the landholder fails to comply with an order under sub-paragraph (8), or

where the seller has not applied for an order under that sub-paragraph, the landholder has not (having regard to the period fixed by or agreed under sub-paragraph (4)) within a reasonable period from the acquiring by the landholder of the right to buy otherwise concluded missives with the seller for the sale of the land to the landholder.

Where the price to be paid for land is not agreed between the seller and the small landholder as mentioned in paragraph 53(2)(a), the land is, except where sub-paragraph (2) applies, to be valued by a valuer appointed by agreement between the seller and the landholder or by a person nominated by them.

This sub-paragraph applies where the land in respect of which the landholder is exercising a right to buy forms part of an estate comprising other land in respect of which any other landholder has given notice under paragraph 51 of the landholder’s intention to buy.

intro.p: Where sub-paragraph (2) applies, the land mentioned in that sub-paragraph is to be valued by—
a valuer appointed by agreement between—

content.p: the seller, and
at least half of the landholders mentioned in that sub-paragraph, or
a person nominated by the persons mentioned in paragraph (a)(i) and (ii).
Where there is no agreement as to the appointment of a valuer under sub-paragraph (1) or (3), the valuer is to be appointed by the Land Court or by a person nominated by the Court.
In this Part, “valuer” includes two valuers with an overseer.

intro.p: A valuer appointed under paragraph 54 is to assess the value of the land in respect of which a small landholder’s right to buy under paragraph 50 is being exercised as at—

content.p: the date of notice under paragraph 48 of the seller’s proposal to transfer the land, or
where no such notice was given, the date on which the landholder gave notice under paragraph 51 of the landholder’s intention to buy the land.

intro.p: The valuer is to assess the value of the land having regard to the value that would be likely to be agreed between a reasonable seller and buyer of such land—

content.p: assuming that the seller and buyer are, as respects the transaction, willing, and
where the buyer is a sitting small landholder.

intro.p: In assessing the value of the land under sub-paragraph (2), the valuer is to take account of—

content.p: in so far as a seller and a buyer of the land (assuming that they are, as respects the transaction, willing) would do so, any factor attributable to the known existence of a person who (not being the landholder who is exercising a right to buy the land) would be willing to buy the land at a price higher than other persons because of a characteristic of the land which relates peculiarly to that person’s interest in buying it,
when the seller would in the normal course of events have been likely to recover vacant possession of the land from the landholder,
the terms and conditions of any lease of sporting interests affecting the land, and
any moveable property belonging to the owner of the land which is, by agreement between the landholder and the owner, to be sold with, and valued along with, the land.

intro.p: In assessing the value of the land under sub-paragraph (2), the valuer is to take no account of—

content.p: the absence of the period of time during which the land would, on the open market, be likely to be advertised and exposed for sale,
any factor attributable to any use of the land which is or would be unlawful,

any increase in the value of the land resulting from improvements to the extent that the landholder would be entitled to compensation in respect of those improvements upon renouncing the tenancy of the small landholding,
any increase in the value of the land resulting from the use of any of the land, or changes to the land, for a purpose other than cultivation of the land,

intro.p: any reduction in the value of the land—

content.p: as a result of any dilapidation or deterioration of, or damage to, fixed equipment or land caused or permitted by the landholder, or
resulting from the use of any of the land, or changes to the land, for a purpose other than cultivation of the land, or
any fixed equipment owned by the landholder.

intro.p: Where land in respect of which the right to buy is being exercised forms part of an estate, the valuer is, in addition to assessing the value of the land under sub-paragraph (2), to assess the value representing the difference between—

content.p: the value of the estate were the estate being sold by the seller to a person other than the landholder, and

the value of the remainder of the estate (that is to say, the estate less the land in respect of which the right to buy is being exercised) were the remainder being sold by the seller to such a person.

intro.p: Where two or more parts of an estate are being bought in exercise of a right to buy under this Part—
the valuer is to assess—

content.p: the value of each of those parts under sub-paragraph (2), and
the difference between the values mentioned in paragraphs (a) and (b) of sub-paragraph (5),

wrapUp.p: as at the last date on which notice of intention to buy was given under paragraph 51 in respect of those parts of the estate,

content.p: the valuer may, for the purpose of valuation under sub-paragraph (5), apportion to each such part of the estate (or re-apportion if for any reason the sale of any such part does not proceed) such amount representing the reduction in the value of the estate as the valuer considers equitable.
The Scottish Ministers may issue guidance (either generally or in respect of a particular description of case) for the purposes of valuation under this paragraph.

intro.p: An estate is to be treated, for the purposes of sub-paragraphs (5) and (6) and paragraph 56, as comprising—

content.p: any land forming part of the estate and which is being bought in exercise of a right to buy under this Part, and
any other land forming part of the estate offered for sale by the seller at the same time as the land mentioned in paragraph (a).

intro.p: For the purposes of paragraph 53(2)(b)(i), the price payable by a landholder is—

content.p: the value assessed under sub-paragraph (2), or

intro.p: where the land forms part of an estate, the greater of the values assessed under—

content.p: that sub-paragraph, and
sub-paragraph (5).

intro.p: A valuer appointed under paragraph 54 is—

content.p: to invite the persons mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) to make written representations about the matters mentioned in sub-paragraph (3), and
to have regard to any such representations.

intro.p: The persons are—

content.p: the seller and the small landholder to whom the assessment under paragraph 55 relates, and
where the land to which the assessment relates forms part of an estate, any other person the valuer considers to have an interest in the estate.

intro.p: The matters are—

content.p: the valuation of the land under paragraph 55, and
where the land forms part of an estate, any valuation of the estate (and any apportionment of a reduction in the value of the estate) under that paragraph.

intro.p: The valuer may, for the purposes of any assessment under paragraph 55—

content.p: enter onto land, and
make any reasonable request of the seller and landholder.

The valuer must, within the period of 6 weeks beginning with the day on which the valuer is appointed, give the seller and the landholder a notice in writing specifying the price payable by the landholder under paragraph 55(9) and setting out how the price was calculated.

intro.p: The expenses of the valuer accrued in carrying out the valuer’s functions under paragraph 55 and this paragraph are to be—

content.p: met by the landholder, or
where sub-paragraph (2) of paragraph 54 applies, shared equally between the landholders mentioned in that sub-paragraph.

intro.p: The seller is liable to the landholder for any expenses met by the landholder by virtue of sub-paragraph (6) where—

content.p: the Land Court has made an order under paragraph 53(8),
the landholder to whom the order applies has complied with the order, and
the seller does not proceed with the sale of the land to the landholder.
The Scottish Ministers may by regulations make further provision for or in connection with the matters provided for in this paragraph and paragraphs 54 and 55.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Appeal to Lands Tribunal against valuation

content.p: The seller or the small landholder to whom a valuation carried out under paragraph 55 relates may appeal to the Lands Tribunal against the valuation.

intro.p: An appeal under this paragraph must—

content.p: state the grounds on which it is being made, and
be lodged within the period of 21 days beginning with the date of the notice under paragraph 56(5).

intro.p: In an appeal under this paragraph, the Lands Tribunal may—

content.p: reassess any value of the land (and any factor affecting the value) or of an estate (and how any reduction in the value of an estate is to be apportioned), and
for the purposes of paragraph 53(2)(b)(ii), determine the price.
The valuer whose valuation is appealed against may be a witness in the appeal proceedings.

intro.p: In the appeal proceedings, in addition to the seller and the landholder, the following persons are entitled to be heard—
where the seller is—

content.p: a creditor in a standard security, the owner of the land,
the owner of the land, any creditor in a standard security over the land or any part of it,

intro.p: where the land forms part of an estate—

content.p: any creditor in a standard security over any other land forming part of the estate,
any landholder, or other tenant, of any such land.
The Lands Tribunal is to give reasons for its decision on an appeal under this paragraph and is to issue a written statement of these reasons.
The decision of the Lands Tribunal in an appeal under this paragraph is final.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Referral of certain matters by Lands Tribunal to Land Court

content.p: This paragraph applies where, in an appeal before the Lands Tribunal under paragraph 57, an issue of law arises which may competently be determined by the Land Court by virtue of section 1(6) of the Scottish Land Court Act 1993 or this Act.
The Tribunal is to refer the issue to the Land Court for determination unless the Tribunal considers that it is not appropriate to do so.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Registration of small landholder’s interest: power to modify provisions

content.p: The Scottish Ministers may by regulations make provision for or in connection with the registration under this Part of small landholders’ interests in buying the land comprised in their landholdings.

intro.p: In particular (but without limit to that generality), regulations under sub-paragraph (1) may—
make provision about—

content.p: the manner in which a small landholder notifies the owner of the land of the landholder’s interest in buying the land,
the procedure by which that interest is (or may be) registered,
how an application for registration and entry in the Register may be challenged,
the effect of registration,
the Keeper’s functions in respect of registration,
the updating or correction of entries in the Register,
the consequences of an application for registration, or an entry in the Register, being inaccurate in a material regard,
the expiry or cancellation of an entry in the Register,
modify paragraphs 44 to 50,
if the Scottish Ministers consider it necessary or expedient, make consequential provision which modifies the other provisions in this Part.

intro.p: Before laying a draft of a Scottish statutory instrument containing regulations under sub-paragraph (1) before the Scottish Parliament, the Scottish Ministers must consult—

content.p: the Keeper, and
such other persons as the Scottish Ministers consider are likely to have an interest in the registration of interests to buy land under this Part.

intro.p: In this Part—

content.p: eligible creditor has the meaning given by paragraph 48(6),
Keeper has the meaning given by paragraph 44(1),
